analyzeResult.content:
Battelle-PM Methods
P.3
NOV 05 '97 11:20AM PHILIP MORRIS R&D T7
Titie
Method
Comments
Results
PH MS, Richmond, PM Collect smoke from 1 cigarette in
USA
two water filled impinger traps, 50 [ml of water per trap, followed by a Cambridge pad. Liquid and pad combined for measurement of pH and Redox at 20 minutes
Adding Cambridge pad gives better representation of the pH of whole smoke. However, the pad has a basic organic binder. The blank pad pH varies from lot to lot and by manufacturer.
IM15 pH of 5.45 (RSD = 2.01%) and Redox of 61.52 mV vs. Ag/AgCI (18%)
PH MS, Battelle
Collect smoke from 1 cigarette two water filled impinger traps, 20 mL water per trap, no Cambridge pad. pH measurment in front trap at 5 minutes and Redox measurement in both traps at 20 minutes.
Not using the Cambridge pad avoids the issue of binder pH and buffering capacity of the pad binder
1R4F pH of 5.07 (RSD'= 0.76%) and Redox of 108 mV vs. Ag/AgCI (12%) for front impinger and 77 mV (19%) for back impinger
MS Formaldehyde, Acetaldehyde and Acrolein, Richmond, PM USA
Collect smoke from 1 cig. for TPM > 2 mg or 5 cig. for TPM < 2 mg in 2 impingers containing 20 mL each | Addition of base stabilizes FA and AA.
acidified 2,4-DNPH solution. Neutralize solution with pyridine following smoke collection. HPLC analysis of aldehyde derivatives.
Uses perchloric acid, full recovery for HCHO and ACR, 75% for AA
AA dimer not included in calculation.
1R4F: HCHO = 28.9 ug/cig (RSD = 11%), AA = 659.1 (7%), ACR = 72.7 (7%), LOQ = 0.37 ug/cig HCHO, 0.05 AA, 0.13 ACR
MS Formaldehyde, Acetaldehyde and Acrolein, Battelle
Collect smoke from 4 cig in 1 impinger containing 50 ml of acidified 2,4-DNPH solution (in ice bath) followed by Cambridge pad. Combine pad with solution. HPLC analysis of aldehyde derivatives
Uses HCL acid, does not neutralize the solution following smoking, 90% recovery for all 3 analytes. Includes ACR dimer in ACR analysis. 1R4F ACR results are high compared to literature, TDL, and FTIR
1R4F: HCHO = 29 ug/cig (RSD = 8%), AA = 761 (RSD = 2%), ACR = 126 (ASD = 5%), LOQ = 0.4 ug/cig HCHO, 0.4 AA, 0.3 ACR
MS FTIR Vapor Phase, Richmond, PM purged sample looped containing
USA
Collect smoke directly into nitrogen Acetaklehyde, CO, NO, and HCN, and |1R4F: AA = 788 ug/cig (RSD == 6.1%), CO =
an IR gas cell for direct analysis by FTIR on a pull by puff basis
cos
10,500 (11.4%), HCN = 101 (14.5%), NO = 304 (7.6%), COS = 21 (11.3%)
MS FTIR Vapor Phase, Battelle
Same as PM Method, Instrumentation assembled in Richmond and delivered to Battelle
Acetaldehyde, CO, NO, and HCN. Large difference in AA and CO.
1R4F: AA = 609 ug/cig (RSD = 9.7%), CO = 7536 (11.8%), HCN = 91 (16.4%), NO = 274 (9.5%)
2505161223
)
Page 1

cells.content: Titie
Method
Comments
Results

PH MS, Richmond, PM
USA

Collect smoke from 1 cigarette in
two water filled impinger traps, 50 [ml of water per trap, followed by a Cambridge pad. Liquid and pad combined for measurement of pH and Redox at 20 minutes
Adding Cambridge pad gives better representation of the pH of whole smoke. However, the pad has a basic organic binder. The blank pad pH varies from lot to lot and by manufacturer.
IM15 pH of 5.45 (RSD = 2.01%) and Redox of 61.52 mV vs. Ag/AgCI (18%)
PH MS, Battelle
Collect smoke from 1 cigarette two water filled impinger traps, 20 mL water per trap, no Cambridge pad. pH measurment in front trap at 5 minutes and Redox measurement in both traps at 20 minutes.
Not using the Cambridge pad avoids the issue of binder pH and buffering capacity of the pad binder
1R4F pH of 5.07 (RSD'= 0.76%) and Redox of 108 mV vs. Ag/AgCI (12%) for front impinger and 77 mV (19%) for back impinger
MS Formaldehyde, Acetaldehyde and Acrolein, Richmond, PM USA

Collect smoke from 1 cig. for TPM > 2 mg or 5 cig. for TPM < 2 mg in 2 impingers containing 20 mL each |
acidified 2,4-DNPH solution. Neutralize solution with pyridine following smoke collection. HPLC analysis of aldehyde derivatives.

Uses perchloric acid, full recovery for HCHO and ACR, 75% for AA
Addition of base stabilizes FA and AA.
AA dimer not included in calculation.
1R4F: HCHO = 28.9 ug/cig (RSD = 11%), AA = 659.1 (7%), ACR = 72.7 (7%), LOQ = 0.37 ug/cig HCHO, 0.05 AA, 0.13 ACR
MS Formaldehyde, Acetaldehyde and Acrolein, Battelle
Collect smoke from 4 cig in 1 impinger containing 50 ml of acidified 2,4-DNPH solution (in ice bath) followed by Cambridge pad. Combine pad with solution. HPLC analysis of aldehyde derivatives
Uses HCL acid, does not neutralize the solution following smoking, 90% recovery for all 3 analytes. Includes ACR dimer in ACR analysis. 1R4F ACR results are high compared to literature, TDL, and FTIR
1R4F: HCHO = 29 ug/cig (RSD = 8%), AA = 761 (RSD = 2%), ACR = 126 (ASD = 5%), LOQ = 0.4 ug/cig HCHO, 0.4 AA, 0.3 ACR

MS FTIR Vapor Phase, Richmond, PM
USA

Collect smoke directly into nitrogen
purged sample looped containing
an IR gas cell for direct analysis by FTIR on a pull by puff basis

Acetaklehyde, CO, NO, and HCN, and
cos
MS FTIR Vapor Phase, Battelle
Same as PM Method, Instrumentation assembled in Richmond and delivered to Battelle
Acetaldehyde, CO, NO, and HCN. Large difference in AA and CO.
